awd_titl_txt: Attaining Configuration and Ligand Field Control over the Singly Occupied Molecular Orbital (SOMO)/Fermi Gap in Molecular Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) Films
awd_abstract_narration:
Surfactants are molecules that contain water-soluble and water-insoluble regions. When added to water, surfactants form well-organized films as thin as a single molecule, and this film can be transferred onto a solid surface. Surfactant molecules can be designed to incorporate metal centers to form a new and advanced class of metallosurfactants that can be tailored to respond to specific electrical stimuli. With funding from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Claudio Verani and his research group at Wayne State University in Detroit are studying how to design and obtain new responsive metallosurfactants, and how to tune the properties of these metallosurfactants to respond to specific stimuli.  The team also considers how to use these metallosurfactants to form responsive films on solid surfaces. This research is fundamental to concepts such as directional electron transport needed in quantum computing and stimuli-responsive materials. The outreach goals foster the dissemination of cutting edge scientific knowledge, graduate and undergraduate education and research, and the diffusion of scientific ideas to broader audiences. 

Professor Verani and collaborators are studying the synthesis, redox, electronic, and interfacial behavior of metallosurfactants, both in solution and as Langmuir-Blodgett monolayer films deposited onto electroactive surfaces. This interdisciplinary project aims to study the modulation of the Singly Occupied Molecular Orbital (SOMO)/Fermi gap on metallosurfactant films based on metal ions with distinct 3d0, 3d1, 3d2, 3d3, and 3d4 electronic configurations.  The team also develops push/pull asymmetric metallosurfactants to study the relationship between orbital distortion and directional electron transport, and generates methodology to enable a new class of "on demand" ionic metallosurfactants obtained through the exchange of counterions by charged surfactants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

OUTCOMES REPORT FOR GRANT NSF- CHM-1904584

The work related to proposal CHM-1904584, titled “Attaining Configuration and Ligand Field Control over the SOMO/Fermi Gap in Molecular LB Films” is summarized here. Fundamental to this research is the development of molecular systems that present the ability to control directional electron transport, or rectification. This control is relevant to molecular electronics and quantum computing, a priority among the NSF Big Ideas portfolio. The molecules investigated here are deposited in between two electrodes, and must have the ability to transport electrons from electrode 1 to electrode 2, while preventing the return of these electrons from electrode 2 to electrode 1. This rectification is possible when the energy of the electrode and the molecule are similar after the application of a certain voltage. To be useful, the design of the molecules have to fulfill several requirements, such as (i) they must be asymmetric, (ii) they must have regions capable of accepting and regions capable of donating electrons, (iii) they must show surfactant properties to allow for the formation of films as thin as the length of a single molecule. While the theoretical considerations for such systems were known since the 1970s, the first all-organic systems only appeared in the 1990s, and systems containing metals were first introduced in the 2000s.

Because little is known about how to modulate the energies of the electrode and the molecule, we worked with the design of molecules that allow us to interrogate the influence of (i) the organic ligand around the metal ion, known as ligand field, (ii) the number of unpaired electrons in the metal, known as electronic configuration, and (iii) the use of polar groups attached to the ligand to facilitate the energy matching.

We have shown in six peer-reviewed papers published in top journals the following results:

  1. Early on, we demonstrated in 2 papers (Chemistry European Journal 2019, 25, 14048 and Langmuir, 2020, 36, 14173) that energy mismatch between electrode and molecule, although undesired for electron transport, has the ability to prevent natural oxidative processes on metallic surfaces. In other words, the fact that these systems are bad at transporting electrons allow them to be good corrosion coatings.
  2. We also demonstrated in 2 other papers (J. Phys. Chem. 2022, 126, 21010 and 2023, 127, 16654) that different electron transport mechanisms take place in molecules containing metals with 1, 3, 4, or 5 unpaired electrons. Each of these species show distinct mechanisms that can be advantageous to the design of more efficient systems.
  3. We showed in two other papers (Dalton Transactions, 2022, 51, 8425 and 2023, 52, 12423) that molecules containing ruthenium surrounded by strongly polar groups will allow for electron transport because the ligand and metal pathways become entangled and at close energy. This result allow us to design molecules that are extremely stable because of the metal selection, and show transport, because of the ligand selection.

This understanding of molecular rectification moves the pursuit of fundamental research towards next-generation computing expected to benefit society at large at a time when quantum computing flourishes and promises the processing of gigantic amounts of information. We are accelerating innovation for new materials, and making possible, like Edison did in the 1880s when he selected carbonized bamboo filaments for incandescent light bulbs, that molecule-based computing become a reality.
